Boston.com
10

Pilgrim nuclear plant, union reach contract agreement

Management and unionized workers at the Plymouth plant have a tentative agreement. Union membership is schedule to vote tomorrow. (AP, 7:18 a.m.)
  • 6/18 Coakley challenges relicensing of Pilgrim plant

Cambridge mulls NYC-type soda ban

Following in the footsteps of New York City, Cambridge is considering limiting the size of sodas and sugar-sweetened beverages in city restaurants. (Globe)
Pictures | Where Boston ranks

Boston No. 1 for same-sex couples

The city took the top spot for neighborhoods with the highest percentage of same-sex female couples. Click through to see where Boston ranks for other surveys.

4 years later, Ohio still pivotal turf

The $85 billion auto bailout might not be enough to guarantee President Obama the same overwhelming support he received in the state in 2008. (Globe)
  • Battleground Ohio: Romney hopes to ride 2010 wave
  • pictures Scenes from the presidential campaign trail

Despite millions spent, Boston lags behind other major cities in recycling

Over the past five years, Boston has nearly doubled its recycling rate, yet fewer than 20 percent of waste gets recycled - significantly less than other large cities. (Globe)
  • Discuss How often do you recycle?

Syria to evacuate families from Homs

Syria's government says it is ready to evacuate the roughly 1,000 families trapped in the rebel-controlled central city without preconditions. (AP)
  • 6/18: Syrian activists report renewed shelling in Homs

Romney’s stance on
Syria a work in progress

The decision to walk cautiously on the issue has highlighted Mitt Romney’s difficulty in trying to turn a still-developing military issue to his advantage.

Chain accused of scheming on pay

After Upper Crust was ordered to pay employees nearly $350,000 in OT, executives devised a scheme to wrest the money back, according to the chain’s former CFO.

Drug review process has many critics

As the BIO International Convention opened in Boston, a FDA plan to make decisions on new drugs more transparent drew criticism from industry skeptics.
Opinion | Joanna Weiss

Revealing the boundaries of taste

The controversy over the use of a severed head in the likeness of George W. Bush in "Game of Thrones" shows we do still have some standards of respect.

Shirley prison superintendent ousted

The chief of the state’s main maximum-security prison was ousted this month, after less than a year in the post, state officials said.
Art Review

Capturing a landscape of loneliness

Painter Marsden Hartley’s unease and unmatched talent are distilled in “Soliloquy in Dogtown,” a tight but captivating exhibition at the Cape Ann Museum.

Fiona Apple dares you, and you listen

Rutgers webcam spy convict due to get out of jail

The former Rutgers student convicted of using his webcam to watch his roommate kiss another man is due to be released from jail after serving 20 days of a 30-day sentence.

Scott Brown accepts Kennedy debate with conditions

Senator Scott Brown said he will accept a debate at the Edward M. Kennedy Institute, but only on the condition that Vicki Kennedy stay neutral in the election and MSNBC drop out as the sponsor.

Business

Microsoft unveils Surface tablets

One of the tablets will be 9.3 millimeters thick. It will come with a kickstand to hold it upright and a keyboard that is part of the device's cover. It weighs under 1.5 pounds.

Personal Finance

7 ways to save at the movies

The average movie ticket price in 2011 rose to $7.93 from $7.89 the year before, according to the National Association of Theatre Owners. If there's a film you don't want to miss at the theater, here are some ways to cut costs.
